fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition it suffices to show that \Pi _{(z:A)}\Pi _{(q:x=_Az)} \Pi _{(w:A)}\Pi _{(r:z=_Aw)} (\text {refl}_x\cdot q)\cdot r = \text {refl}_x\cdot (q\cdot r) Let q:x=_Az and r:z=_Aw. By computation rule of identity types \text {refl}_x\cdot q \equiv q Then we can conclude that (\text {refl}_x\cdot q)\cdot r \equiv q\cdot r similarly \text {refl}_x\cdot (q\cdot r) \equiv q\cdot r. Hence we have the left and right side (\text {refl}_x\cdot q)\cdot r = \text {refl}_x\cdot (q\cdot r) are judgementally equal, so we can simply define the associator as \text {assoc}(\text {refl}_x,q,r) :\equiv \text {refl}_{q\cdot r}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a type. These are 3 consecutive identifications p:x=_Ay,q:y=_Az, r:z=_Aw we define the associator: \text {assoc}: (p,q,r): (p\cdot q)\cdot r = p\cdot (q\cdot r)

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition it suffices to show that \Pi _{(z:A)}\Pi _{(q:x=_Az)} \Pi _{(w:A)}\Pi _{(r:z=_Aw)} (\text {refl}_x\cdot q)\cdot r = \text {refl}_x\cdot (q\cdot r) Let q:x=_Az and r:z=_Aw. By computation rule of identity types \text {refl}_x\cdot q \equiv q Then we can conclude that (\text {refl}_x\cdot q)\cdot r \equiv q\cdot r similarly \text {refl}_x\cdot (q\cdot r) \equiv q\cdot r. Hence we have the left and right side (\text {refl}_x\cdot q)\cdot r = \text {refl}_x\cdot (q\cdot r) are judgementally equal, so we can simply define the associator as \text {assoc}(\text {refl}_x,q,r) :\equiv \text {refl}_{q\cdot r}
